title: AMA Episode on Nutrition
content: In this “Ask Me Anything” (AMA) episode, Peter answers a wide range of questions from readers and podcast listeners. Bob Kaplan, Peter’s head analyst, asks the questions.

title: Impact of Stress on Health
content: The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health | Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D. (#51 rebroadcast)

title: Lipids
content: Peter wants Triglycerides < 100 mg/dL and LDL-P < 1,000 nmol/L. For more on lipids, LDL-P, and LDL-C, listen to the podcasts with Ron Krauss, Dave Feldman, and Tom Dayspring.

title: Inflammation and oxidation markers
content: Peter recommends hsCRP < 1 mg/L and oxLDL < 40 U/L for inflammation and oxidation markers.

title: Metabolic
content: Peter recommends Uric acid < 5.0 mg/dL, ALT < 20 U/L, and AST < 20 U/L for liver function tests. For OGTT, Peter recommends fasting glucose < 90 mg/dL.

title: Blood glucose and insulin levels
content: Fasting insulin should be less than 6 (uIU/mL). 1-hour glucose should be less than 130 and 1-hour insulin should be less than 30. 2-hour glucose should be less than 100 and 2-hour insulin should be less than 20.

title: Thyroid hormones
content: TSH, free T3, reverse T3, and T4 need to be taken in context to make a diagnosis of hypothyroid. TSH tells about the pituitary gland's view of T4 to T3 conversion. fT3 tells about the peripheral T4 converting to T3. rT3 tells about the peripheral T4 converting to rT3, which opposes T3.

title: Sex hormones
content: DHEA, FSH, LH, DHT, progesterone, SHBG, estrone, estradiol, and estriol are the sex hormones that need to be measured. It is a complex process to measure these hormones.

title: Omega-3s
content: EPA and DHA are the two types of omega-3s. The EPA/DHA index should be above 8.5. The sources of these things (e.g., supplements, food) also matter.

title: Cholesterol synthesis and absorption biomarkers
content: Desmosterol, campesterol, sitosterol, and cholestanol are the cholesterol synthesis and absorption biomarkers that need to be measured. Desmosterol is a way to gauge the oversuppression of cholesterol synthesis at the individual level.

title: IGF-1
content: IGF-1 is a marker that is impacted by amino acid intake, insulin levels, and exogenous hormones. Cycling between low and high levels of IGF-1 is optimal. Fasting can dramatically lower IGF-1. IGF-1 is more stable than GH.

title: Women's Health
content: Women have a more stark drop off in hormones than men. Women experience profound fluctuations in hormones during their reproductive years. Women lose estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone. Peter's pet peeve is doctors that disregard perimenopausal and postmenopausal symptoms in women. Women were studied far less than men in early clinical trials for new drugs. Women get less cardiovascular disease, but more Alzheimer's disease. Women get less cancer in the US.

title: Fasting and Ketosis for Females
content: Women need to be thoughtful about a couple of things when considering fasting and ketosis. Fertility issues or trying to get pregnant can't make a compelling case that a woman should be in nutritional ketosis. In a calorie-restricted state, when ketones are elevated, it suppresses FSH and LH in women but not in men. It's certainly possible to get pregnant in ketosis, but the question is how are you optimizing? As a general rule, not convinced it's the best strategy: far better strategy is don't eat junk food, less sugar, etc.

title: Advice for Medical Students and Residents
content: Don't study pre-med in college. All that stuff is like JV version of med school, and you'll get the full version in med school.

title: Maintain a balance
content: It is important to get out of those books for a while and do something pleasant. Probably better off only studying 85 hours instead of 100, for instance, and use those other 15 hours to enjoy life for a minute.

title: Monetizing a podcast
content: Peter wants to figure out a way for the podcast to 1) cover the cost of research, and 2) wishful that it will also generate a pool of capital to invest in types of research he wants to see at universities. Monetization of the podcast will likely be one of these two rather than running ads.

title: Blood glucose monitor
content: Peter uses CGM, the G6, and loves the Oura Ring. He thinks that hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is 'directionally tolerable but mostly shit'.

title: Lithium supplementation
content: Peter says that the evidence that groundwater containing higher levels of lithium is contributing to better mental health is as good as any such data can be which is to say 'not great' (Tier 2 epidemiology).

title: Peter's experiment with lithium
content: Peter experimented on himself to see if taking lithium would stabilize his mood. First consulted with Paul Conti, a psychiatrist who uses lithium in monotherapy for high-risk bipolar patients who don’t respond well (or at all) to the common bipolar drugs. Peter was taking 600 mg/day (about half what a bipolar patient would take). Did this for about a year, didn’t tell anyone, because he figured that if there truly were noticeable differences and wanted to see if others noticed on their own. The first person to notice was Peter’s wife, she noticed after 4 months. When Peter asked how she knew, her response was, “You’re less of an asshole”. Peter decided not to continue to take a mega dose of lithium (he did notice some side effects such as nausea). Peter now takes low dose 10-20 mg lithium. He categorizes this as “probably not harmful, [but] not sure how much value I’m getting out of it”.

title: Insights about berberine
content: Berberine, a plant-derived extract with 2 properties. First, it is a weak activator of AMP kinase (the “secret sauce” of Metformin is that it activates AMP kinase). OTC dose is generally 500-1000 2x per day (similar to Metformin). The net effect is decreasing hepatic glucose output, “poor man’s version of Metformin”. Secondly, the more exciting piece is that it is a weak inhibitor of the enzyme, PCSK9. Word on the street, it probably only works in a subset of people who overexpress PCSK9 (an enzyme [technically a proprotein convertase: it acts more like a chaperone than a catalytic enzyme] that degrades LDL receptors) which ends up in higher LDL-P (only about 5% of the time will this be the reason someone isn’t clearing LDL particles, there are literally thousands of possible reasons). These patients respond well to berberine.

title: Why does Peter take a baby aspirin? What does the science say?
content: But the reason he was doing so is that heart disease is rampant in Peter’s family so he is simply trying to mitigate risk. Baby aspirin has some effect on inflammation, but the majority of the benefit is on platelets, therefore reducing thrombotic events (blood clot), which can be the final moment where you have an MI. A month ago, his view was . . . if your “Aspirin Works Test” is positive (test in urine that measures metabolites of platelets to predict which patients will respond to baby Aspirin) combined with at least one other factor that indicates possible heart disease, he would recommend taking it. There are side effects to be considered, easier bruising, bleeding, a small risk of ulcer, etc. Study that came out recently that looked at relatively low-risk populations, found that the risk of taking baby aspirin was small, but so was the benefit, making it a “wash” in Peter’s mind. Now he’s just a little less likely to suggest (this especially to low risk patients). Will Peter stop taking it? Perhaps, even though it makes sense intuitively, the data simply don’t support it.

title: How do you use HR variability as a metric in your practice and/or in your own personal use?
content: HRV measures the specific changes in time (i.e., variability) between successive heartbeats. The raw measurement is the interbeat interval (IBI): IBI is used in reference to the time interval between individual beats of the heart.

title: HRV Domains
content: HRV can be expressed in 2 domains: time or frequency. The Oura ring shows time domain, which is expressed in raw RMSSD (Root Mean Square of Successive RR Differences). Frequency-domain methods: frequency domain methods assign bands of frequency and then count the number of RR intervals that match each band.

title: Oura Ring and HRV
content: Oura doesn’t show frequency domains because they claim that the low-frequency to high-frequency (LF/HF) ratio often does not accurately measure cardiac sympathovagal balance. Oura does claim that it could provide an accurate measure of sympathovagal balance because of the high precision of the IBI measurement from the ring.

title: HRV and Sleep Quality
content: HRV with temperature and movement feeds an algorithm in Oura that predicts sleep quality. Alcohol and unhealthy food close to bedtime will drive HR way up, and HRV way down, which diminishes your recovery and sleep quality.

title: Real-time Feedback and Readiness Score
content: Real-time feedback is crucial to improving HRV. If your HRV is off in the morning when you wake up you can immediately ask what did I do differently? The readiness score is not as sensitive to lifting workouts. It is valuable to know your readiness score to improve sleep quality.

title: Fasting and Sleep
content: Fasting can improve sleep quality. Deep sleep (stage 3 and 4) went up the most, light slight (stage 1 and 2) went down the most, REM was unchanged, HRV was higher, resting HR was on par with what it is if you’re not eating and drinking before bed, and respiratory rate went down.

title: Saturated Fat and Nutrition Epidemiology
content: The case for saturated fat may be overstated, the view that it is never harmful and eating 90% of saturated fat can’t be healthy for everyone. Rather than rely on some “knucklehead” study, Peter suggests that we “learn to understand what the biomarkers are that changes as a result of [consuming saturated fat],” meaning inflammation, lipoproteins, and lipids.

title: Moderate Carbohydrate Intake and Health
content: The paper that claims moderate carbohydrate intake may be best for health suffers from all the problems of nutritional epidemiology, a horrible brand of science.

title: Critique of a research paper
content: Zoe Harcombe wrote a great article on this which points out that the paper: Didn’t correct for alcohol consumption, Has a number of odd confounders, Hazard ratios are quite low, Risks are discussed in relative terms instead of absolute terms.

title: Number one recommendation for wholesome health
content: Peter not a huge fan of this type of question. The “glib” answer is to: Sleep well, Do something physical, Don’t eat for a long period, When you do eat, don’t eat crap, Meditate. With that said, “sleep is the one we are going to be most sensitive to”. Lack of good sleep is the one you will “suffer from the quickest”.

title: Reasons for difficulty in getting into ketosis
content: If the concern is that the person does not get to the same levels of BHB (beta-hydroxybutyrate), the first two things Peter would consider are the following: Perhaps they are more efficiently utilizing the ketones (hard to demonstrate outside of a laboratory), Just producing less of them due to something different they are doing than what they were doing in the past (changed fatty acid consumption, eating more protein, more carbs).

title: Peter's approach to reducing the risk of atherosclerotic disease
content: Peter has an all-hands-on-deck approach defined as: Reducing the burden of lipoproteins, Reducing inflammation, Improving endothelial health, Increasing insulin sensitivity. As for choosing Zetia (ezetimibe) and Lipitor (atorvastatin) specifically: Lipitor, empirically derived, trial and error, found that taking 10 mg 3x per week when coupled with the Zetia, minimum effective dose got Peter to below the 20th percentile.

content: Plot: Peter’s little known alternate life as a shepherd (wink wink). Release date: Early 2020.

title: Thoughts on nicotinamide riboside supplementation for longevity
content: Cells need NAD, so you could argue having more NAD in a cell is a better thing (second order question). But cells cannot take up NAD, a cell has to be able to make its own. With that said, giving precursors is an interesting idea. Referencing the paper in Cell Metabolism by Josh Rabinowitz. They developed a tracer to track all the intermediaries of NAD and all the precursors. When given oral precursors (NR or NMN), only the liver could take them up and make NAD using tryptophan, no other cell could take it up. So if you’re taking oral NR or NMN, you are pretty much just giving it to your liver, not the place you want it to be (not changed by using pterostilbene). Based on data, only way to increase cellular NAD would be intravenous doses of NR or NMN. Taking it orally is probably not harmful, but probably waste of money. For more on NAD, see episode of The Drive with David Sinclair as well as Dave Asprey’s podcast episode with Charles Brenner.

title: Supplement Brands Recommended by Peter Attia
content: Jarrow, Pure Encapsulations, Nordic Naturals, Carlson Labs, and Thorne are supplement brands that Peter Attia recommends.
